transcriptText:
The Kushti wrestlers have been doing knees over toes hack squats for centuries, and personally I started doing them in 1999 after reading "Combat conditioning" by Matt Furey. They are called Bethaks/ Baithaks, aka Hindu squats or deep knee bends.

There are many variations performed by the wrestlers for conditioning, and Georges Hackenschmidt, a wrestler himself, did Hack squats, with an external load held behind the back.

Hindu squats mobilize your toes, and challenge balance, mobility and strength.

They also  combine nicely with Indian club swinging, whether you're using light or heavy clubs.

In this video, I just demonstrate 2-3 simple ways to perform them. If you do not have Indian clubs, get a pair of our Pahlavandle or try swinging the arms. You'll probably have to work on your balance and timing.

To learn step by step how to swing Indian clubs,

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

❂ READY TO LEARN MORE?

All our educational material has been tested and structured since 2010, in a way that is easy for anyone to learn from home.

hey terry from eric sport welcome to the channel so in this video today i want to show you a couple of knee over toes exercise we do with the indian clubs i'm going to show you a light club variation and a heavy club variation let's go so if you know little about traditional indian physical culture you know that the hindu wrestlers the khushi wrestlers perform an exercise called baitec which is basically a neo-toe squat okay so the heels are definitely off the ground the upper body is as straight or erect as possible knees definitely over the toes the hamstrings are resting on the calves okay and these are usually done with an arm swing and perform at high reps okay um so we're gonna use that model of squatting to combine it with the indian club so first i'm gonna demonstrate with the light clubs here using our power bundle that screws onto solar pop bottles okay whoa whoa whoa not so fast remember to subscribe like and leave us a comment so based on an outer meaning going away from the midline heart shape means we've got a back circle combined with the front circle okay so this is the swing and now as elevate the clubs i'm gonna drop into my squat okay so i've got an overhead squat if you've got problems coordinating the movement it's best to start in this position and then lower the arms as you raise up okay so as soon as they go behind you you extend the arm you descend into your squat personally i prefer to open my knees out it doesn't affect my gait okay i still walk my toes pointing forward uh i don't walk funny so don't stress about it okay so here we are boom get up descend okay and high speed and so on okay and you could even combine it with the snake you know many ways you can do this anyway on to the heavier club so heavier club swung with one hand okay i'm gonna actually this time have my inner swing boom like this and maybe change direction drop under the weight as i catch it with the straight arms in my overhead squat okay this is here boom as i get up because it's heavy club i bring it down to my guard position away from the body boom i go into my head parry and at the same time i drop under the weight so again you know maybe you want to start in this position first straighten up order away head parry drop under the weight okay so we got the club going up the body going down same kind of ideas if you're doing a barbel snatch for example boom and that's that hope you like the series and keep on swinging bonus exercise variation with the reverse nordic standing on your knees can you even see that i don't know so tall kneeling let's say okay i've got the top of my swing here if i go straight down i'm going to hit the ground not cool so as i the arms come down i'm gonna go into a reverse knee extension and straighten up again okay so here's another way where you can combine indian clubs and knees of a toes exercise [Music]

![Thumbnail (1920x1080)](https://i.ytimg.com/vi_webp/U2XiHpCl-Js/maxresdefault.webp)
# [Bethaks/ Deep knee bends /Knees over toes exercises with Indian clubs (intermediate)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U2XiHpCl-Js)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2021-05-28T10:00:11-07:00
**Published at**: 2021-05-28T10:00:11-07:00
**Length**: 03:56
**Views**: 2313
**Likes**: 123
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
The Kushti wrestlers have been doing knees over toes hack squats for centuries, and personally I started doing them in 1999 after reading "Combat conditioning" by Matt Furey. They are called Bethaks/ Baithaks, aka Hindu squats or deep knee bends. 
There are many variations performed by the wrestlers for conditioning, and Georges Hackenschmidt, a wrestler himself, did Hack squats, with an external load held behind the back.
---
Hindu squats mobilize your toes, and challenge balance, mobility and strength.
They also  combine nicely with Indian club swinging, whether you're using light or heavy clubs. 
In this video, I just demonstrate 2-3 simple ways to perform them. If you do not have Indian clubs, get a pair of our Pahlavandle or try swinging the arms. You'll probably have to work on your balance and timing.
---
If you get knee pain doing these, it's probably a question of too much too soon. Find a regression that is pain free first. You have to earn your right to do them, so go and do reverse step ups first as shown here: https://youtu.be/P9i1ziDXa5U
⏰TIMESTAMPS⏰
0:00 intro
0:16 Bethaks
0:50 light clubs variation 
2:06 heavy club variation
3:11 reverse Nordics variation
---
GO TO: https://heroicsport.com/product-category/buy-indian-clubs/ and check out the whole selection of clubs we have!
☛DISCOUNT CODE FOR 10% OFF YOUR SET OF ADJUSTABLE INDIAN CLUBS PAHLAVANDLE™: gen9
---
To learn step by step how to swing Indian clubs, 
GO TO: https://heroicsport.com/product-category/indian-clubs-tutorials-beginners/
☛DISCOUNT CODE FOR 30% OFF TRAINING VIDEOS: startswingin 
---
WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS
Watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft-FL_6s_No
---
〄 PHYSICAL ASPECTS
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)
〄 MENTAL ASPECTS
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ and the Pahlavandle™XL to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

❂ READY TO LEARN MORE?
We run instructor certifications (online and live), team building events and offer video downloads on our website at https://heroicsport.com/indian-clubs-online/
All our educational material has been tested and structured since 2010, in a way that is easy for anyone to learn from home.
```
